sentences.sentence: He found himself in the neighborhood of the asteroids( 小行星 ) 325, 326, 327, 328, 329, and 330.
He began, therefore, by visiting them, in order to add to his knowledge.
The first of them was inhabited( 居住 ) by a king.
Clad in( 穿着... ) royal purple and ermine( 白鼬毛皮 ), he was seated upon a throne( 王座 ) which was at the same time both simple and majestic( 威严的 ).
“Ah! Here is a subject( 臣民 ),” exclaimed( 感叹 ) the king, when he saw the little prince coming.
And the little prince asked himself:
“How could he recognize me when he had never seen me before?”
He did not know how the world is simplified for kings.
To them, all men are subjects( 臣民 ).
“Approach, so that I may see you better,” said the king, who felt consumingly( 极其地 ) proud of being at last a king over somebody.
The little prince looked everywhere to find a place to sit down; but the entire planet was crammed( 塞满的 ) and obstructed( 堵塞的 ) by the king’s magnificent( 华丽的 ) ermine( 白鼬皮毛 ) robe( 长袍 ).
So he remained standing upright( 笔直地 ), and, since he was tired, he yawned( 打呵欠 ).
“It is contrary to etiquette( 礼节 ) to yawn( 打呵欠 ) in the presence of( 当着...的面 ) a king,” the monarch( 君主 ) said to him. “I forbid( 禁止 ) you to do so.”
“I can’t help it. I can’t stop myself,” replied the little prince, thoroughly embarrassed( 尴尬的 ). “I have come on a long journey, and I have had no sleep . . .”

“Ah, then,” the king said. “I order you to yawn( 打呵欠 ). It is years since I have seen anyone yawning( 打呵欠 ). Yawns( 呵欠 ), to me, are objects of curiosity. Come, now! Yawn( 打呵欠 ) again! It is an order.”
“That frightens me . . . I cannot, any more . . .” murmured( 嘟囔 ) the little prince, now completely abashed( 窘迫的 ).
“Hum! Hum!” replied the king. “Then I—I order you sometimes to yawn( 打呵欠 ) and sometimes to—”
He sputtered( 语无伦次地说 ) a little, and seemed vexed( 生气的 ).
For what the king fundamentally insisted upon was that his authority( 权威 ) should be respected.
He tolerated( 宽恕 ) no disobedience( 违抗 ).
He was an absolute( 专制的 ) monarch( 君主 ). But, because he was a very good man, he made his orders reasonable.
“If I ordered a general,” he would say, by way of example,
“if I ordered a general to change himself into a sea bird, and if the general did not obey me, that would not be the fault of the general. It would be my fault.”
“May I sit down?” came now a timid( 羞怯的 ) inquiry( 询问 ) from the little prince.
“I order you to do so,” the king answered him, and majestically( 威严地 ) gathered in a fold of his ermine( 白色鼬皮 ) mantle( 斗篷 ).
But the little prince was wondering . . . The planet was tiny.
Over what could this king really rule?
“Sire( 陛下 ),” he said to him, “I beg that you will excuse my asking you a question—”
“I order you to ask me a question,” the king hastened( 急忙 ) to assure( 确定地对...说 ) him.
“Sire( 陛下 )—over what do you rule?”
“Over everything,” said the king, with magnificent( 极其的 ) simplicity.
“Over everything?”
The king made a gesture, which took in his planet, the other planets, and all the stars.
“Over all that?” asked the little prince.
“Over all that,” the king answered.
For his rule was not only absolute( 专制的 ): it was also universal( 宇宙的 ).
“And the stars obey you?”
“Certainly they do,” the king said. “They obey instantly. I do not permit insubordination( 不服从 ).”
Such power was a thing for the little prince to marvel( 惊叹 ) at.
If he had been master of such complete authority( 权力 ), he would have been able to watch the sunset, not forty-four times in one day,
but seventy-two, or even a hundred, or even two hundred times, without ever having to move his chair.
And because he felt a bit sad as he remembered his little planet which he had forsaken( 离开 ), he plucked up his courage( 鼓起勇气 ) to ask the king a favor:
“I should like to see a sunset . . . Do me that kindness . . . Order the sun to set . . .”
“If I ordered a general to fly from one flower to another like a butterfly, or to write a tragic drama, or to change himself into a sea bird,
and if the general did not carry out( 执行 ) the order that he had received, which one of us would be in the wrong?” the king demanded. “The general, or myself?”
“You,” said the little prince firmly.
“Exactly. One must require from each one the duty which each one can perform,” the king went on.
“Accepted authority( 权力 ) rests first of all on( 以...为基础 ) reason. If you ordered your people to go and throw themselves into the sea, they would rise up in revolution( 革命 ).
I have the right to require obedience because my orders are reasonable.”
“Then my sunset?” the little prince reminded him: for he never forgot a question once he had asked it.
“You shall have your sunset. I shall command it. But, according to my science of government, I shall wait until conditions are favorable.”
“When will that be?” inquired( 询问 ) the little prince.
“Hum! Hum!” replied the king; and before saying anything else he consulted( 查阅 ) a bulky( 庞大的 ) almanac( 年历 ).
“Hum! Hum! That will be about—about —that will be this evening about twenty minutes to eight. And you will see how well I am obeyed.”
The little prince yawned( 打呵欠 ).
He was regretting his lost sunset.
And then, too, he was already beginning to be a little bored.
“I have nothing more to do here,” he said to the king. “So I shall set out on my way again.”
“Do not go,” said the king, who was very proud of having a subject( 臣民 ).
“Do not go. I will make you a Minister!”
“Minister of what?”
“Minister of—of Justice!”
“But there is nobody here to judge!”
“We do not know that,” the king said to him.
“I have not yet made a complete tour of my kingdom. I am very old. There is no room here for a carriage. And it tires me to walk.”
“Oh, but I have looked already!” said the little prince, turning around to give one more glance to the other side of the planet. On that side, as on this, there was nobody at all . . .
“Then you shall judge yourself,” the king answered. “That is the most difficult thing of all. It is much more difficult to judge oneself than to judge others.
If you succeed in judging yourself rightly, then you are indeed a man of true wisdom.”
“Yes,” said the little prince, “but I can judge myself anywhere. I do not need to live on this planet.”
“Hum! Hum!” said the king. “I have good reason to believe that somewhere on my planet there is an old rat. I hear him at night.
You can judge this old rat. From time to time you will condemn him to death( 判...死刑 ).
Thus his life will depend on( 取决于 ) your justice. But you will pardon him on each occasion; for he must be treated thriftily( 节约地 ). He is the only one we have.”
“I,” replied the little prince, “do not like to condemn anyone to death( 判...死刑 ). And now I think I will go on my way.”
“No,” said the king.
But the little prince, having now completed his preparations for departure( 离开 ), had no wish to grieve( 使难过 ) the old monarch( 君主 ).
“If Your Majesty( 陛下 ) wishes to be promptly( 迅速地 ) obeyed,” he said, “he should be able to give me a reasonable order.
He should be able, for example, to order me to be gone by the end of one minute. It seems to me that conditions are favorable . . .”
As the king made no answer, the little prince hesitated( 犹豫 ) a moment.
Then, with a sigh, he took his leave.
“I made you my Ambassador( 大使 ),” the king called out, hastily( 匆忙地 ).
He had a magnificent( 极其的 ) air( 神态 ) of authority( 权威 ).
“The grown-ups( 成年人 ) are very strange,” the little prince said to himself, as he continued on his journey.

article_info.previous: “我”更进一步了解了小王子的花儿，那是一朵天真而骄傲的花。但最终小王子决定离开她去旅行，而他的花也没有求他留下来。
article_info.share_words: "It is much more difficult to judge oneself than to judge others. If you succeed in judging yourself rightly, then you are indeed a man of true wisdom.”

question.cn: 谁住在小王子拜访的第一颗行星上？
question.en: Who lived on the first planet that the little prince visited?

analysis: 原文提到：He began, therefore, by visiting them, in order to add to his knowledge.The first of them was inhabited by a king.  所以答案为A。

question.cn: 为什么小王子当着国王的面打呵欠？
question.en: Why did the little prince yawn at the presence of the king?

options.en: Because he didn't respect the king.

options.cn: 因为他认为打呵欠是一种礼节。
options.en: Because he thought it was an etiquette to yawn.

analysis: 原文提到：So he remained standing upright, and, since he was tired, he yawned.所以答案为B。

question.cn: 在这颗行星上，谁是国王的臣民？
question.en: Who was the subject of the king on the planet？

analysis: 原文中小王子提到：“Oh, but I have looked already!” said the little prince, turning around to give one more glance to the other side of the planet. On that side, as on this, there was nobody at all . . . 所以答案为C。

question.cn: 为了让小王子留下来，国王给出了什么条件？
question.en: What did the king offer to ask the little prince to stay?

options.cn: 让他当司法部长或者大使。
options.en: Making him the Minister of Justice and also the Ambassador.
Making him the prince of his kingdom.

analysis: 原文中，国王提到：“Do not go. I will make you a Minister!”“Minister of what?”“Minister of—of Justice!”以及“I made you my Ambassador,” the king called out, hastily. 所以答案为A。

share_title: 100天读完4本英文书，今天是第6天
